items.title: Jason Buenrostro named core institute member at Broad
items.content_text: An expert in epigenetics and longtime member of the Broad community, Buenrostro will focus on how life experiences can alter the epigenome and increase risk of disease.

items.title: #WhyIScience Q&A: A structural biologist adopts a new role catalyzing collaborations
items.content_text: A former drug discovery scientist, Gail Guo now helps advance research into novel cancer drugs as part of Broad’s alliance with Bayer.

items.title: Remembering David Baltimore
items.content_text: David Baltimore served as Chair of the Broad Institute Board of Scientific Counselors, was a member of our Board of Directors, and was essential in the formation of the Broad Institute itself. We asked our Founding Director, Eric S. Lander, to share some reflections with the Broad community.

items.title: Mass General Brigham launches genetic test to predict risk across eight cardiovascular conditions
items.content_text: Developed in collaboration with Broad Clinical Labs and Mass General Brigham Laboratory for Molecular Medicine, the test provides a comprehensive view of a patient’s inherited heart disease risk. div.hero-section__author { display:none;}

items.title: How massive datasets generated at Broad are powering the latest AI models in biology
items.content_text: Broad scientists describe how data resources they helped build over more than a decade now form the foundation for cutting-edge AI and genome biology discoveries.

items.title: Evolved gene editor inserts entire genes in human cells
items.content_text: The new system is the first to use a DNA-mobilizing enzyme called a CRISPR-associated transposase to make targeted gene-sized edits at therapeutically useful levels in human cells.

items.title: Gene editing extends lifespan in mouse model of prion disease
items.content_text: A single-letter edit in DNA reduces levels of the disease-causing prion protein in the brain and could lead to a preventative, one-time treatment for the deadly neurodegenerative disorder.

items.title: Scientists engineer CRISPR enzymes that evade the immune system
items.content_text: The new genome-editing tools could lead to safer, more efficient gene therapies.

items.title: Researchers devise new way to target and correct disease-related proteins
items.content_text: Broad scientists built a diverse library of compounds and found one that stabilizes a dysfunctional protein in Crohn’s disease, demonstrating their library’s potential to uncover new therapeutic strategies.

items.title: New drug triggers rapid cell death in cancer models
items.content_text: BRD-810 inhibits the MCL1 protein and reactivates apoptosis in tumor cells, displaying therapeutic potential in animal models.
